metadata.synopsis: Al Lewis (George Burns) and Willy Clark (Walter Matthau) are a pair of feuding vaudeville comedians (Lewis and Clark, naturally) who performed together for 47 years before finally calling it quits. A network genius then has the brilliant idea of reuniting the duo for a TV special about the history of comedy. Once the reunion is on, the sparks and one-liners start to fly with equal speed. But can Lewis and Clark put aside their differences long enough to collect one last paycheck?

reviews: It is a very empty comedy about the meaning of reconciliation and the decline of vaudeville actors. [Full review in Spanish]
If you're unfamiliar with Simon, Ross or Stark, The Sunshine Boys is a must; if otherwise, give a look at least for the acting.

A one-trick pony with a hundred jokes about encroaching dementia. It was hilarious when I was 16, but now that I often wander into the living room from the kitchen and can't remember what I went in there for--it's less funny. Which is kinda funny.
The film hungers for a reconciliation at fade-out, but instead of effecting it naturally Simon has to rig it out with ugly quarrels, professional breakdowns and heart attacks.
I'm afraid it would be a rainy day in hell before The Sunshine Boys would be anything more than an afternoon matinee flick for the Actor's Home For The Aged.
Walter Matthau y George Burn reach that tragic emotion where the passage of time indicates the irreversible decline of things. [Full Review in Spanish]
...suffers from a terminally arms-length atmosphere that's compounded by filmmaker Herbert Ross' stagy approach to the material...
Aging comics sparkle, swear, and spar in Neil Simon farce.
Great chemistry between the two great comic leads and some pretty decent one-liners but this doesn't manage to hold together as a feature-length concept.
One of the best films ever made from a Neil Simon play.

Herbert Ross' version of Neil Simon's Broadway production is still a play--verbose and repetitious at that--but it's well acted by Walter Matthau and George Burns (who won an Oscar) as the two cranky vet vaudevillians.
It's generally an appealing and witty film because the leads are outstanding as cranks.

The Sunshine Boys is an extremely sensitive and lovable film version of Neil Simon's play, with Walter Matthau and George Burns outstanding in their starring roles as a pair of long-hostile vaudeville partners.
Mr. Matthau is so good playing old men, we may never know when he finally becomes one.
